message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at 298 K and 1 atm pressure?
message_2:
The standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at 298 K and 1 atm pressure can be determined using the balanced chemical equation for the combustion reaction and the standard enthalpies of formation for the reactants and products.

The balanced chemical equation for the combustion of methane is:

CH4(g) + 2 O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2 H2O(l)

The standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) at 298 K for the substances involved in the reaction are:

ΔHf° [CH4(g)] = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf° [O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol (since it is in its elemental form)
ΔHf° [CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf° [H2O(l)] = -285.8 kJ/mol

Using the formula for calculating the standard enthalpy change of the reaction (ΔHr°):

ΔHr° = Σ [ΔHf° (products)] - Σ [ΔHf° (reactants)]

ΔHr° = [1 × (-393.5) + 2 × (-285.8)] - [1 × (-74.8) + 2 × 0]

ΔHr° = (-393.5 - 571.6) - (-74.8)

ΔHr° = -965.1 + 74.8

ΔHr° = -890.3 kJ/mol

Therefore, the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at 298 K and 1 atm pressure is -890.3 kJ/mol.
